metadata.title: On Bullshit in Art and Data Science | by Merzmensch | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: On Bullshit in Art and Data Science
metadata.description: Yes, exactly. You read it. Neither BS nor Bulls**t. Simply: Bullshit, or to be more precise, “pseudo-profound Bullshit”. This is not a profanity anymore, but a scientific term, at least after the…

outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: Judgment and Decision Making Volume 14, Number 6, November 2019
generating Art with StyleGAN and other GANs

all_paragraphs: Yes, exactly. You read it. Neither BS nor Bulls**t. Simply: Bullshit, or to be more precise, “pseudo-profound Bullshit”. This is not a profanity anymore, but a scientific term, at least after the paper “Bullshit makes the art grow profounder” (PDF, in the following, referred to as BSS) saw the light of day last November (in Judgment and Decision Making Volume 14, Number 6, November 2019)
The main message of the research is about the role of meaning in art:
Previous research on aesthetic preferences demonstrates that people have a general dislike of art that they consider meaningless (BSS).

In the Digital Age, the tendency for AI-generated (abstract) images is emerging, and the deception of viewers as well, according to the study. Providing abstract paintings with titles makes them appearing as profound. And with AI-generated titles, they evoke so-called “pseudo-profound bullshit”, especially in those cases when the artist (=curator of own AI-generated artwork) tries to gain “social advantages”. They are fooling around with innocent viewers, who trustfully hopes, everything was intended:
Randomly generated pseudo-profound bullshit titles increased the perceived profoundness of computer-generated abstract art, compared to when no titles were present (BSS).
The study doesn’t only aim to raise awareness against art fraud (low-cost AI-art production for high valuation at the art market), but also scrutinizes the accountability of abstract artists as such:

Some abstract artists have embraced a radically subjective view toward art, that is to say there is no possible objective standard for beauty or meaning. These artists maintain a goal to impress a sense of depth or beauty, while going further than merely not being concerned about truth, but instead denying that any objective truth could possibly exist (BSS).

If the world of abstract art does in fact represent an ideal environment for bullshit to be deployed as an effective lowcost strategy for gaining prestige, then one would expect the presence of bullshit to be widespread in this domain.(BSS).
Therefore, there are several goals this study follows:
In my opinion, the study walks the thin ice between ignorance of art theory and pseudo-psychological strategies.
Let’s analyze the study into four aspects.

Every psychological research needs human statistics. They should be accountable and reliable. If we look at the probands of this study (there are several studies within a paper), we will see some interesting details:
The study evaluates real abstract artworks (MoMA as source) and AI-Generated images, combined with AI-generated (“pseudo-profound bullshit”) and human-created (“mundane”) titles.
AI-Generated titles tend for metaphysical ideas (“The Pathological Interior”), mundane titles are rather visual descriptions of artwork (“Colour Mixing”).

The emphasis of the examination is on the fact whether abstract uncomprehended art is received by probands differently, if with given titles (“AI-generated” vs “mundane”). The setup of this research is surprisingly anti-academic (lack of intertextuality, just referring to subjective reception instead).
The present study (BSS) tries to use the argumentation of alleged deception by titles for the incrimination of abstract artists.

There is the continuous concretization of social advantages, significance, and art value — all components belonging to the Art Market Sector. With no word is the possibility mentioned, that an artist might express himself by his artwork without any intentions for monetarization.

The Distinguishing, even the juxtaposition between Artwork (as individual artists expression) and Art Market (as artwork monetarization platforms) is not only remarkable, it is inevitable in the light of critical discourses of XXst century about the abrogation of authority in art.
The main anticonventional Art Disruptors were Dadaists, Surrealists, and Abstractionists — precisely the target group of exposure in the present study.
Ironically, if a subjective view of beholders is handled with appreciate respect in this study, the subjective motives of artists are not.

Plain said, the study wants to prove that giving a title to abstract painting is a Pseudo-Profound Bullshit (especially if all components are AI-generated) — with further skepticism about the relevance of abstract art as such.
Let’s look at some artworks and titles of the exposed groups.

“Le Tombeau des Lutteurs” (“The Tomb of the Wrestlers”)— what a pseudo-profound BS title! At first glance. In this title, Magritte quoted a novel by the French Symbolist Léon-Alpinien Cladel “Ompadrailles, le tombeau des lutteurs” (1879). Behind this caption is — as always in case of Magritte — a sophisticated cultural and sociopolitical story, based on letter exchange with New Yorker Lawer and Poet Harry Torczyner about Soviet ‘tachiste’ painters, about European situation of the 1960ies, etc…
Magritte was a master of weird titles — with the exception that the “weirdness” was only “weird” for non-informed viewers. (#Cultural Competence)

This is MERZ-Bau installation by Dadaist and MERZ-Artist Kurt Schwitters. His transmedial spatial installation was filling several rooms in his apartment in Hannover. When he exiled from Nazi Germany to Norway, he kept building Merz-Baus everywhere he lived, without any hope (and also intention) to make this work famous, to monetarize it, or to gain any social advantage. He did it just because he couldn’t stop creating. It was his life.

The title “Cathedral of Erotic Misery” is highly narrative: about his meanderings, about cultural discourses of his time, about political collapses of pre-WWII, about his personal situation. This title was abolished and renamed to Merz-Bau as Schwitters’ Œuvre was presented by Nazis in their sarcastic Exhibition “Entartete Kunst” (Degenerate Art Exhibition, 1937). The main task of the exhibition was to juxtapose abstractionists and Avant-Gardists with their (for fellow citizens incomprehensible and quasi-profound) narratives and visuals versus “pure” and politically approved and useful Realism and Commissioned Art by Nazi Regime.
Limits of Reason (“Grenzen des Verstandes”). Now, this is a perfect pseudo-profound Bullshit, isn’t it?

No, it is not. In this abstract work, Paul Klee explored in an ironic way the philosophy of Bauhaus. Initially, Klee worked as a lecturer for Bauhaus, but its raising focus on technologic tendencies and utility-fixated rationalism made Paul Klee skeptical about this art school and movement. In this abstract painting, the artist expresses the pathetic idolization of pragmatism by Bauhaus.

As you see, behind these — for the first glance, “pseudo-profound” titles — is always a colossal narrative, which will be fully comprehensible only by viewers who is aware of the background. Here emotional art becomes an intellectual one.

“Well”, you will say, “but what about all those dazzlers and copycats, who are generating Art with StyleGAN and other GANs, and applying random metaphysical titles using title generators like this or this. And then sell it on Sotheby’s for big money? Is it Pseudo-profound Bullshit?”
Well, yes, but only if you don’t buy it (intended pun).
Because AI-generated content creates new narratives. New genre. New profoundness.
According to the Oxford dictionary, the term “Bullshit” means
ideas, statements or beliefs that you think are silly or not true.
It’s up to you to believe or not. To speak on the artist’s frequency or to reject. You don’t need a study for this, especially if this study is infected with biases and stereotypical generalizations.
After all, even the random combination of AI-generated art (using Artbreeder) and title (using TitleGen) can build a new narrative (if you open your mind and follow your imagination).
You will only claim for being fooled by “pseudo-profound Bullshit” if you take art — and the life — way too seriously.
Mind the wise advise, GPT-2 driven model gave me, as I asked it about “what is meaning of life”:
And fortunately, I am not alone with this opinion:
What do you think, my friends?
Your home for data science. A Medium publication sharing concepts, ideas and codes.
Futurist. AI-driven Dadaist. Living in Germany, loving Japan, AI, mysteries, books, and stuff.
